title: Nowton Park Walking Route

images.title: Bob Jones / Nowton Park
images.caption: Nowton Park. Footpath and trees on a summer day.

images.title: Oxyman / Exotic tree, Nowton Park
images.caption: Exotic tree. The park has examples of trees from all over the world.

images.title: Oxyman / Carved dragon, Nowton Park
images.caption: Carved dragon. One of several sculptures at the site.

images.title: Simon Peck / Font in Nowton Park
images.caption: A font beside the School Pond in Nowton Park. It was created by the Oakes family, and also includes a distressed archway and font The font is believed to have originated from St Peters Church in Nowton village. The archway was brought here from St Marys Church in 1831.

images.title: Oxyman / Picnic area, Nowton Park
images.caption: View of the picnic area with daffodils in March 2008.

images.title: Bob Jones / Lime Avenue, Nowton Park
images.caption: Lime Avenue. The northern end of the avenue of trees, by the car park and main entrance. The Lime Avenue was planted around 1880 to give the estate a sense of grandeur and to provide the house (then Nowton Court) with a vista to its northern boundary. The trees here are 40m high. Over 100,000 daffodils were planted in 1989, the two species being King Alfred and Magnificent.

images.title: Oxyman / Nowton Park Car Park
images.caption: Car Park. A view of the good sized parking area at the site.

images.title: Oxyman / Small Footbridge in Nowton Park (2)
images.caption: Small Footbridge in the park.

description: Explore 200 acres of beautiful Suffolk countryside landscaped in a beautiful Victorian style in this country park in Bury St Edmunds. There are well maintained footpaths taking you around the park with good facilities including a visitor centre and cafe. The park is located just over a mile to the south of Bury St Edmunds town centre so can be easily reached on foot. The Bury to Clare Walk runs just past the park so there is scope for continuing your walk if you have time.
